newsitem.title: GABON: Cocoa producers agree output cut targets - minister.
newsitem.headline: Cocoa producers agree output cut targets - minister.

text.p: Cocoa ministers finalised agreement on Tuesday on output targets designed to cut world production by 90,000 tonnes over the next three years, Ivory Coast's commodities minister said.

"Member countries have each set a range of objectives with an average figure meeting the targets," Guy-Alain Gauze told Reuters at a two-day ministerial review in Gabon of the 1993 International Cocoa Agreement.
"The figures match World Bank and IMF (International Monetary Fund) recommendations and are realistic," he said on Tuesday.
The plan envisages cutting total output by 15,000 tonnes in 1996/97, by 30,000 in 1997/98 and by 45,000 in 1998/99.
The 90,000-tonne cut was initiallly agreed at meetings in September of the International Cocoa Organization (ICCO), which groups producers and consumers.
Some producers -- Malaysia, Ghana and Brazil -- had objected over differences between their own output projections and Cocoa Producers' Alliance (CPA) projections.
Gauze said the deal, which aims to balance world supply and demand and protect producer economies, would be signed by Tuesday night.
